complaint_narrative: A Californian resident reports on their experience with a crypto asset trading site operating at avtocoin.com.  The resident transferred over $6,000 to the site to trade cryptocurrency.  When the resident tried to withdraw their money, the platform said their account was suspended for 30 days due to “suspicious activity”.  The resident has been unable to recover any of their money, and the site is no longer operational.

Multiple California residents reported participating in a wealth management course offered by Eagle Crest Asset Management (ECAM), led by an individual identified as “Ridel.” The course focused on stocks and crypto assets trading. The residentswere instructed to open accounts on the crypto asset trading platform operating at OK-Coin (ok-coin.com), QamCoin.com, and Coin-Rush.com.ECAM provided investors with $500 to begin trading. The residents opened accounts and believed they were making profits trading this initial amount. Encouraged by these results, the residents invested their own money and again appeared to earn substantial returns. But when they tried to withdraw funds, the platform demanded commissions taxes, or fees ranging from 8% to 15% of the value of the account. Despite paying these fees, none of the individuals have been able to recover their investments, and none of the associated websites are currently operational.

Multiple California residents report on their experience with a fraudulent crytocurrency trading platform at crypen.com. The residents report joining a WhatsApp group named “Techcrisis Investment Guild.” The group recommended the residents to invest in “TGD” tokens on the platform. Following the group's recommendation, the residents created a crypen.com account and invested funds to purchase “TGD” tokens. However, when the residents attempted to withdraw funds from the platform, their requests were denied unless they paid a "fee." The residents have not recovered their funds. Crypen.com is no longer operational.

A California resident reports they were approached online by “Melissa” who steered the conversation over to WhatsApp. Melissa claimed to have inherited crypto assets, which she used to support various non-profit organizations. Melissa offered to help the resident invest in crypto assets and showed the resident how to open an account on the crypto asset trading platform operating at https://www.defiwa11etbch.com and https://defie-v2.com. Melissa then provided the resident trading signals to make short term trades, saying she could predict the market. The resident traded based on Melissa's signals on the platform for a few weeks, but when the resident tried to withdraw funds from the platform, they were unable to do so. Then, Melissa cut off all communications. The resident has been unable to recover their funds, and the websites are no longer operational. All told, the resident lost $700,000 on the platform.

A California resident reports that they met an individual on Instagram. The individual presented themselves as a young millionaire that resided in New York. The individual convinced the resident to register for a website called “LBMA” to trade“gold spots”. The individual then taught the resident how to transfer cryptocurrency to a fraudulent crypto asset tradingplatform operating at lbmaex.xyz (LBMA).  The resident followed those instructions, and after each transfer to lbmaex.xyz, the individual would “match” the resident’s deposits to increase the resident's trading capacity. In addition, the individual persuaded the resident to liquidate their retirement accounts to invest on lbmaex.xyz. After their largest deposit, the resident attempted to withdraw their funds from the platform, but the platform informed the resident that they could not do so without paying “taxes”. The resident has not paid the “taxes” and has not recovered their funds. lbmaex.xyz is not operational as of the time this narrative is published.

All told, the resident lost at least $300,000.

A California resident reports about the experience with the so-called investment education platform, “Digital Finance Academy” which offered access to a “Trader Incubation Program” called the “Stable Trading System 6.0 investment system”. To participate in the program, the resident paid $50,000 in crypto assets, believing they could net 300% through the issuance of a crypto asset Academy Token (“STS”). Digital Finance Academy claimed that once they had sold enough tokens to reach their target the resident would get their returns, though would have to pay 30% to the academy for various subscription/service-related fees. But after participating in the program, the platform demanded $54,000 for “commissions” before allowing any withdrawals. The resident has not been able to recover their funds and the investment program is no longer operational.The DFPI cautions consumers to be wary of entities purporting to be investment education platforms offering access to proprietary investment programs or technologies to solicit investment in crypto. These entities may promise unusually high returns in vague investment opportunities that appear to be sophisticated or complex (e.g. algorithmic trading systems, AI-driven strategies, etc.) and may even have consumers sign into an investment contract to appear legitimate.

The first victim reports that they watched a video that linked to the “xAI token” presale on official-xai.com. The victim reports that they saw a fake video of “Elon Musk” talking about the coin which led them to believe that the offering was legitimate. The victim then initiated a swap for their DOGE coin and put in more than the minimum due to the promise of attractive “bonuses”. After engaging in multiple “successful” transactions with official-xai.com, the victim reports that official-xai.com told the victim they could receive a larger bonus if they made another presale purchase. The victim then transferred USDT and did not receive any coins in return. The website is now defunct. The victim reports sending cryptocurrency to the following wallet addresses:c4473f3d60ebc2c48ee00ac4a7dd44a19e5f131c596cac047d1bae081514099cDTLcykDRKbgQ8AKsnnnKP9WwZuVD1sFAanDKFXeqPcv4s8nFB4pZxjfu2hwjV8LkwXNzDTLcykDRKbgQ8AKsnnnKP9WwZuVD1sFAanThe second victim reports that they clicked on the link found in a YouTube video and decided to invest on fraudulent platform, https://xai-network.com/home/. The victim sent 2,300 XRP tokens to https://xai-network.com/home/ to swap for the “xAI token” as part of the presale. After sending the XRP tokens and communicating with “customer service”, the victim reports not receiving the “xAI tokens” in return. The platform is no longer available.The above sites are not affiliated with the company, xAI.

A California consumer reports about their experience using the crypto asset trading platform Cointrust.cc operating at https://cointrust1.cc/. After making two deposits to the platform in crypto, the resident was then unable to access or withdraw their funds from the platform.  The website is no longer operational. All told, the resident lost more than $2,400. The resident reports sending ETH to 0x33efb1efc0faeda19003fb4e73e7bc7b8d0c807a.

A California resident reports they were approached online by someone who eventually introduced them to the crypto asset trading platform OSL operating at www.oslvsap.vip. The online friend told the victim they could make large profits on the platform. The victim started with a small investment. Over time, the online friend encouraged the victim to deposit more money on the platform, and at one point, believed their account had grown to more than $140,000. But when the victim tried to withdraw funds, the platform demanded they pay a “20% management fee”. After paying the fee, which amounted to $25,000, the platform demanded they pay an additional $21,000 under the guise of some sort of verification fee. The victim has been unable to recover any funds from the platform, which is no longer operational. All told, the victim lost more than $90,000.

A California resident reported their experience with the crypto asset trading platform Bitfarms operating at https://web.bitfarms.top. After depositing funds on the platform, the victim was able to engage in several successful transactions. But when they tried to withdraw funds, the platform demanded they pay a “mining fee”. The victim paid, but then the platform demanded they pay a “tax bill.” The victim has been unable to withdraw their funds from the platform, which is no longer operational.

A California consumer reports about their experience with an online crypto asset trading platform operating at Invescoin.com. The consumer opened an account on the platform, deposited funds, and the platform appeared to show that the victim earned significant profits. But when the victim tried to withdraw their funds, Invescoin did not respond.The consumer has not recovered any funds. The website is no longer in operation. All told, they lost more than over $159,000.

A California consumer reports about their experience with the crypto asset platform operating at firepin.io. The consumer was led to believe they could purchase a new crypto asset token before it went public. The consumer deposited funds on firepin.io to purchase the token but later requested a refund and received no response. The consumer has not recovered any funds, and the website is no longer operational.

A California resident reports being contacted via LinkedIn and Whatsapp by an individual claiming they could make quick, profitable investments using the crypto asset trading platform YCBIT operating on the website ycbit.com. The resident created and funded an account on the platform and after trading there, believed their account had grown in value. But when the resident tried to withdraw funds, the website demanded multiple payments including a deposit equal to 10% of the withdrawal amount, another deposit equal to 15% of the total balance of the account to confirm identity, and another deposit equal to the total amount in the account, before it would allow a withdrawal. The resident has not recovered any funds and the website is no longer active.

A California resident reports on their experience with the crypto asset trading platform operating on the website kakucoin.com. After creating and funding an account on the platform, the resident believed his account was growing in value. But when the victim tried to make a withdrawal, the site demanded they deposit additional funds first. The victim did so, but was still unable to withdraw funds. The resident has not recovered any funds and the website is no longer active.This is not to confused with legitimate exchange, KuCoin.com.

Multiple California residents report on their experience with a crypto asset venture operating on the website etfswappresale.com. They report the site offered initial coin offerings (ICO’s). But after they deposited funds on the website to invest in the ICO’s, they didn’t get the coins, nor could they get their money back. One victim reported that all their crypto assets were transferred out of their crypto wallet after they clicked on a related website, etfswappresale.live. Neither of the websites are currently active.

A California victim reports on their experience with the crypto asset trading platform operating at stocks-finance.com. After trading on the site, and believing they had made profits, the victim tried to make a withdrawal from their account for an emergency. The platform's customer service first advised the customer to wait a day, then told them their account had been closed or switched to a different crypto account, and then their account balance suddenly showed a negative balance. The victim has been unable to withdraw their funds and the website is not operational.

Dylan convinced the victim to open an account on the trading platform operating at 2bridgeio.com and sell some of their other investments to transfer funds onto that platform. The victim deposited funds on 2bridgeio.com and attempted to withdraw, but has been unable to recover any of their funds.  Thewebsite is no longer operational. Raddy convinced the victim they used an AI trading program that would generate stable returns. Following Raddy’s instructions the victim invested funds on the platform and believed they were earning substantial profits on the platform. A California consumer was approached online by “Amundi TM” who claimed to be a broker representing an investment firm. The alleged broker encouraged the consumer to access to a trading platform at amundi-ltd.com and then offered “margin loans” to facilitate larger trades. After the larger trades appeared to yield profit, the broker demanded the victim repay the margin loan by wiring funds from their bank, rather than from the profits in the account.The consumer did not pay and now has been unable to recover their investment. The site is not operational.

A California resident reports that they were contacted on Instagram by a stranger, who eventually asked that they move the conversations to WhatsApp. At some point, the stranger introduced them to Crypto futures trading on fraudulent platform, ApolloX, operating at the website apolloxxap.com. The victim invested, and believed they were making profitable trades, but when they to withdraw their funds, the ApolloX helpdesk told the resident they suspected “malicious trading” in the account and demanded a $10,400 “security fee”. The resident paid the fee but ApolloX then demanded a “tax” on profits. The resident paid the “tax” but the platform told them that since their account had past issues, they would have to wait to make a withdrawal, unless they purchased a “VIP membership” for $50,000. The victim contacted the stranger who suggested that if the victim could pay $10,000 to ApolloX the stranger would pay the remaining $40,000 for the “VIP membership.” But even after obtaining the VIP membership, ApolloX demanded an additional $20,000 in “withdrawal fees”. The resident has not been able to withdraw their funds and the website is no longer operational.

But then the platform notified the victim their account was being flagged as at risk for money laundering and demanded the victim pay additional funds to verify their account. Lily pressed the victim to open an account on the platform. The victim sent funds but now cannot recover them and the website is no longer operational.

A California resident reports meeting an individual on an online dating app who introduced them to crypto trading website, https://www.atomexc.com/. The resident deposited money onto https://www.atomexc.com/ and believed that the balance in their account was growing. But when the victim tried to withdraw funds, the platform demanded they pay a “tax”. The resident paid the “tax” but then the platform demanded an additional “fee” of $16,000 to complete the withdrawal. The victim did not pay the additional fee and has been unable to recover their funds from the platform. The website is no longer operational. All told, the victim lost more than $14,000.

A Californian reports on their experience trying to buy a crypto token called “Propichain” ($PCHAIN), on the website propichain.finance.  The victim sent money to Propichain but never received any tokens.  When the victim complained to Propichain’s customer support team, their login credentials were blocked.  The victim has not been able to recover any of their money and the website is no longer operational. All told the victim lost $20,000.

A California resident reports meeting an individual on an international dating app, Bumpy. After talking for a few months, the individual encouraged the resident to start investing on crypto asset trading platform, btc01.org. The website is no longer operational. The victim reports losing more than $46,000.

A California consumer discovered Crypto-Networks.net through a promotional YouTube video and decided to use the platform to invest in cryptocurrency. After making a few small deposits that appeared to work, the consumer deposited more crypto assets. Following that deposit, the platform abruptly froze the consumer’s account.When the consumer contacted support, the platform demanded they upgrade to “Titan Status” before they could withdraw funds. The upgrade cost $10,000, which the consumer paid by transferring more crypto assets. Despite transferring the funds, the consumer’s account remained frozen, and the platform stopped responding. The site is no longer in operation and the consumer has not retrieved any of their funds.

Five California residents report on their experience with the crypto asset trading platform Lencoin, which operated on the website www.h5.lencoin.vip. The residents all learned about Lencoin from visiting the website, wealthtutor.com, where a person named “Clark” discussed opportunities to make big profits by investing in crypto coins and using trade signals through Telegram or Whatsapp groups. Clark directed the residents to open accounts on Lencoin to make the trades, and the residents subsequently  transferred their cryptocurrency to Lencoin. The residents believed their accounts were rapidly growing but were met with various excuses when they tried to withdraw funds such as the transaction being flagged for a "money laundering check". Some residents were directed to transfer additional fund as a prerequisite to withdrawal. The residents did not recover their invested funds. Both www.h5.lencoin.vip and wealthtutor.com are no longer operational.

A California resident reports about the experience with the so-called investment education platform, “Digital Finance Academy” which offered access to a “Trader Incubation Program” called the “Stable Trading System 6.0 investment system”. To participate in the program, the resident paid $50,000 in crypto assets, believing they could net 300% through the issuance of a crypto asset Academy Token (“STS”). Digital Finance Academy claimed that once they had sold enough tokens to reach their target the resident would get their returns, though would have to pay 30% to the academy for various subscription/service-related fees. But after participating in the program, the platform demanded $54,000 for “commissions” before allowing any withdrawals. The resident has not been able to recover their funds and the investment program is no longer operational.The DFPI cautions consumers to be wary of entities purporting to be investment education platforms offering access to proprietary investment programs or technologies to solicit investment in crypto. These entities may promise unusually high returns in vague investment opportunities that appear to be sophisticated or complex (e.g. algorithmic trading systems, AI-driven strategies, etc.) and may even have consumers sign into an investment contract to appear legitimate.

Samiya promised high returns from investing in crypto and told the victim to download a crypto wallet app. Samiya then provided instructions on how to open an account on pzmqgow.top and send funds to the platform from the wallet app encouraged the victim to make multiple deposits. A California resident reports meeting an individual on an online dating app who introduced them to short-term crypto asset trading. All told, the victim lost more than $240,000.

complaint_narrative: A California resident reports about their experience with the crypto asset trading platform, VOEX or Voexe. The resident reports that the platform promised a reward of 118,888 USDT if investor deposits exceeded one million by a certain date. When the victim was unable to meet the deadline, Voexe deducted 100,000 USDT from the victim’s account, and demanded even more funds if the victim wanted to withdraw the balance of their account.Based on a screenshot provided by the victim, the platform operated under web domains voex.com and voexit.com, and appears to mimic the look and interface of another crypto trading platform. However, the logo used by the platform is stolen from the robotics solutions company, Vectis Automation. This is not to be confused with Vectis Automation at https://vectisautomation.com/.

After viewing the individual’s Facebook profile, filled with testimonials from other individuals purchasing new cars and houses crediting the platform, the resident reached out saying they were interested. The individual instructed the victim how to open an account to begin trading on the crypto asset trading platform operating at xplivetrade.com, promising a return of $5,500 in three days. A California resident reports encountering a crypto coin offering offered at the web domain, Tesladigital.us. The website touted plans to go public, but continually push back the coin’s anticipated launch date. At one point, the website claimed there were only two days left to purchase “Teslacoin” (TES) as an early investor before it would close for 6 months. The victim decided to invest at $0.95 a share. Later the webiste claimed ES had increased to $17.57 which led the victim to believe their investment was worth $175,000. However, the when the victim tried to withdraw  funds, the website claimed the shares were restricted until the offering goes public. The resident been unable to recover their funds and the website is no longer operational.This is not to be confused with Tesla or any of its ongoing products and services at https://www.tesla.com/. The DFPI warns consumers to remain vigilant against scams fraudulently using the Tesla name, brand, or likeness to promote fake investment opportunities or giveaways. These schemes often appear on social media or spoofed websites, falsely claiming affiliation with Tesla or its executives, and may promise guaranteed returns, free cryptocurrency, or exclusive investment offers. The DFPI encourages consumers to verify the legitimacy of an investment opportunity before sending funds and reporting suspicious activity to the appropriate financial authorities.

The victim has been unable to recover their funds and the website is no longer in operation.

A California resident reports encountering a crypto coin offering offered at the web domain, Tesladigital.us. The website touted plans to go public, but continually push back the coin’s anticipated launch date. At one point, the website claimed there were only two days left to purchase “Teslacoin” (TES) as an early investor before it would close for 6 months. The victim decided to invest at $0.95 a share. Later the webiste claimed ES had increased to $17.57 which led the victim to believe their investment was worth $175,000. However, the when the victim tried to withdraw  funds, the website claimed the shares were restricted until the offering goes public. The resident been unable to recover their funds and the website is no longer operational.This is not to be confused with Tesla or any of its ongoing products and services at https://www.tesla.com/. The DFPI warns consumers to remain vigilant against scams fraudulently using the Tesla name, brand, or likeness to promote fake investment opportunities or giveaways. These schemes often appear on social media or spoofed websites, falsely claiming affiliation with Tesla or its executives, and may promise guaranteed returns, free cryptocurrency, or exclusive investment offers. The DFPI encourages consumers to verify the legitimacy of an investment opportunity before sending funds and reporting suspicious activity to the appropriate financial authorities.
